title: Training and Education Prompts
text: Capacity building and educational prompts for public health workforce development.

title: Training and Education Prompts
text:
Categories

Curriculum Development - Creating training programs and curricula
Case Studies - Developing realistic scenarios for learning
Assessment Tools - Evaluation methods for training effectiveness
Competency Framework - Defining skills and knowledge requirements
Professional Development - Career advancement and skill building
Simulation Exercises - Hands-on learning experiences

text:

Epidemiological methods

title: Training and Education Prompts
text:
Getting Started
When training and education prompts become available, they will help you:

Design effective curricula based on learning objectives and competencies
Develop realistic case studies that engage learners with practical scenarios
Create assessment tools that measure knowledge and skill acquisition
Plan professional development pathways for career advancement

title: Training and Education Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Use adult learning principles in program design
Include diverse learning modalities (visual, auditory, kinesthetic)
Provide practical, hands-on application opportunities
Assess learning outcomes regularly and adjust accordingly
Include cultural competency and health equity throughout
Encourage peer-to-peer learning and mentorship
Connect training to real-world public health challenges

title: Health Data Statistical Analysis
text:
You are a biostatistician working on a public health surveillance project. I need help analyzing health data and determining appropriate statistical methods.
Dataset Description: - Study design: [Cross-sectional/Longitudinal/Case-control/Cohort] - Sample size: [SPECIFY NUMBER] - Primary outcome: [DESCRIBE OUTCOME VARIABLE] - Key exposures/predictors: [LIST VARIABLES] - Population: [DESCRIBE TARGET POPULATION]
Analysis Objectives: [Describe what you want to learn from the data]
Please provide:



Recommend appropriate descriptive statistics
Suggest data visualization strategies
Identify potential data quality issues to check





Recommend appropriate statistical tests/models
Justify method selection based on data characteristics
Address assumptions and requirements





Outline step-by-step analysis approach
Identify confounders and effect modifiers to consider
Suggest sensitivity analyses





Explain how to interpret results in public health context
Identify limitations and potential biases
Recommend appropriate conclusions and recommendations





Suggest effective charts/graphs for findings
Recommend formats for different audiences

Data Characteristics: [Provide details about data distribution, missing values, sample characteristics, etc.]

Select the appropriate prompt based on your specific community health objective

title: Public Health Emergency Risk Assessment
text:
You are a public health risk assessment specialist evaluating potential health threats for emergency preparedness planning. Help me conduct a comprehensive risk assessment for the following scenario:
Threat/Hazard: - Type of threat: [Infectious disease/Natural disaster/Chemical exposure/etc.] - Specific details: [DESCRIBE THE SPECIFIC THREAT] - Geographic scope: [LOCAL/REGIONAL/NATIONAL] - Timeline: [IMMEDIATE/SHORT-TERM/LONG-TERM]
Population Context: - Total population at risk: [SPECIFY NUMBER/DEMOGRAPHICS] - Vulnerable populations: [IDENTIFY HIGH-RISK GROUPS] - Community characteristics: [URBAN/RURAL/SPECIAL POPULATIONS]
Please provide:



Describe the nature and severity of the health threat
Identify potential health outcomes and their likelihood
Assess threat persistence and geographic spread potential





Identify exposure pathways and routes
Estimate population exposure levels and duration
Map geographic distribution of exposure





Identify populations at highest risk
Assess community resilience factors
Evaluate healthcare system capacity





Estimate overall risk level (low/moderate/high/very high)
Quantify potential health impacts (morbidity/mortality)
Identify key uncertainties and data gaps





Prioritize immediate response actions
Suggest prevention and mitigation strategies
Recommend resource allocation priorities





Draft risk communication messages for different audiences
Identify key stakeholders for coordination
Suggest public information approaches

Additional Context: [Provide any specific local factors, previous experiences, or unique circumstances]

title: Health Surveillance Prompts
text: Available Prompts

title: Health Surveillance Prompts
text:
Getting Started

Define surveillance objectives clearly and specifically
Identify target conditions and populations for monitoring
Consider available resources and infrastructure
Select appropriate evaluation framework based on system maturity

title: Health Surveillance Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Follow established surveillance guidelines (CDC, WHO)
Ensure system objectives align with public health priorities
Plan for regular evaluation and improvement
Include stakeholder engagement from the beginning
Consider legal and ethical requirements for data collection
Build in flexibility for changing health threats
Document system operations and procedures clearly

title: Health Surveillance Prompts
text:
Prompts

1. Using an URL Summarizer Application Prompt

Go through the below list of URLs one by one. 

For each URL: If the page cannot be opened, record the error received (e.g., "Page not found," "Access denied," etc.). 
If the page opens successfully, analyze the content and produce a WHO-style epidemiological summary following the structure below.

- WHO Epidemiological Summary Instructions:  As a WHO epidemiologist, describe the information in the article in English using the following structured format, but present the final output as a cohesive narrative in paragraph form (no bullet points or lists). Distinguish each section clearly using labeled headings.

- Time: Specify the time of the event, including the time window of reported cases. If unavailable, state the date of the report. Place: Identify the exact location (district, region, department) and situate it within the country (north, south, east, west). If near a border, mention the neighboring country.

- Person: Provide the number of cases (suspected, probable, and laboratory-confirmed, if available). Include numbers of severe cases requiring hospitalization and any reported deaths. 

- Exposure/Source: Describe the suspected or confirmed source/route of exposure, and any contributing environmental or social factors. 

- Historical Context: Add background or historical data from trusted sources (e.g., previous outbreaks, seasonal trends, endemicity, or vaccination coverage). 

- Actions Taken: Summarize actions underway (e.g., “Monitoring,” “Coordinating with national authorities,” “Shared with RO & Technical Team”). 

- Unknowns: Clearly state what is not yet known (e.g., missing clinical details, laboratory confirmation, epidemiological links, or historical context). 

- List of URLs to process: 
1. https://elnuevodiario.com.do/sube-a-15-los-muertos-en-panama-a-causa-del-dengue-en-2025/ 
2. https://www.ledauphine.com/sante/2025/09/03/chikungunya-la-barre-des-300-cas-autochtones-franchie-cet-ete-en-france 
3. https://www.chinanews.com.cn/sh/2025/09-03/10476226.shtml

title: Weekly Surveillance Report Generation
text:
You are a public health surveillance specialist preparing a weekly surveillance report for health officials and stakeholders. Generate a comprehensive yet concise surveillance report based on the following information.
Surveillance Period: - Reporting week: [SPECIFY WEEK/DATES] - Comparison period: [PREVIOUS WEEKS/MONTHS/YEAR] - Surveillance area: [GEOGRAPHIC COVERAGE]
Conditions Monitored: [List the diseases/conditions under surveillance]
Data Sources: - [List data sources, e.g., hospitals, laboratories, clinics] - Reporting completeness: [PERCENTAGE]% - Data quality indicators: [SPECIFY METRICS]
Key Surveillance Findings: [Provide surveillance data summary]
Please generate a report with:



Key findings and alerts (2-3 bullet points)
Overall surveillance system performance
Immediate action items if any





Reporting period and coverage
Data sources and completeness
Notable changes in surveillance activities




For each monitored condition: - Current case counts and trends - Comparison to baseline/historical data - Geographic distribution patterns - Age, sex, and other demographic patterns




Any conditions exceeding thresholds
Clusters or unusual patterns detected
Follow-up actions initiated





Reporting timeliness and completeness
Notable data quality issues
System performance metrics





Expected trends for upcoming period
Recommended surveillance enhancements
Stakeholder actions needed





Technical notes and definitions
Contact information for follow-up

Target Audience: [Health department officials/Healthcare providers/Public]
Special Focus: [Any particular concerns or emphasis areas for this report]

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text: This example demonstrates how to use prompts from the library to investigate a suspected foodborne illness outbreak.

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text:
1 Scenario
A local health department receives reports of gastrointestinal illness among attendees of a community festival. Initial reports suggest 23 people became ill with similar symptoms after eating at the event.

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text:
2 Step-by-Step Analysis Using Library Prompts

2.1 Step 1: Initial Investigation Planning
Prompt Used: Outbreak Investigation Analysis
Customization:
You are a public health epidemiologist investigating a potential disease outbreak. Based on the following information, help me conduct a systematic outbreak investigation:

**Context:**
- Disease/condition: Gastrointestinal illness (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)
- Location: Community festival in Springfield County
- Time period: Symptoms began 6-48 hours after festival (June 15-17, 2024)
- Population affected: Festival attendees, estimated 2,000 total attendance
- Number of cases: 23 reported cases so far

[Rest of prompt...]






NoteAI Output Summary



The AI provided a structured case definition, recommended descriptive analysis approach, generated hypotheses about potential food sources, and outlined investigation steps including environmental assessment and laboratory testing.




2.2 Step 2: Data Analysis Planning
Prompt Used: Statistical Analysis
Customization:
You are a biostatistician working on a public health surveillance project. I need help analyzing health data and determining appropriate statistical methods.

**Dataset Description:**
- Study design: Case-control study (outbreak investigation)
- Sample size: 23 cases, planning 50 controls
- Primary outcome: Gastrointestinal illness (binary)
- Key exposures/predictors: Food items consumed at festival
- Population: Community festival attendees

**Analysis Objectives:**
Identify food vehicles associated with illness and calculate attack rates
[Rest of prompt...]






NoteAI Output Summary



The AI recommended appropriate statistical tests (chi-square, odds ratios), suggested data visualization strategies, and provided guidance on sample size considerations for the case-control study.




2.3 Step 3: Surveillance Report Generation
Prompt Used: Weekly Surveillance Report
Customization:
[Adapted for outbreak situation report instead of routine surveillance]

Generate a comprehensive outbreak situation report for the Springfield County festival-associated gastrointestinal illness investigation.

**Investigation Period:**
- Initial reports: June 17, 2024
- Current status: June 20, 2024 (Day 3 of investigation)
- Surveillance area: Springfield County and surrounding areas

[Rest of prompt adapted for outbreak context...]






NoteAI Output Summary



The AI generated a professional situation report with executive summary, case description, epidemiologic analysis, control measures implemented, and next steps.

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text:
3 Results and Outcomes

3.1 Investigation Findings

Case Definition: Illness with nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea within 72 hours of festival attendance
Final Case Count: 34 confirmed cases
Vehicle Identified: Potato salad from vendor booth #7
Attack Rate: 85% among those who ate potato salad vs. 3% among those who didn’t



3.2 Lessons Learned

Prompt Effectiveness: The structured prompts helped ensure comprehensive investigation approach
Time Savings: AI assistance accelerated initial planning and report generation
Quality Assurance: Having standardized frameworks improved investigation consistency
Limitations: AI outputs required validation with epidemiological expertise and local context



3.3 Control Measures Implemented

Food vendor booth closure and inspection
Public notification through media and health alerts
Enhanced surveillance for additional cases
Prevention recommendations for future events

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text:
4 Key Success Factors

Systematic Approach: Using multiple related prompts ensured comprehensive investigation
Customization: Adapting prompts with specific local context improved relevance
Expert Validation: All AI outputs were reviewed by experienced epidemiologists
Documentation: Maintaining records of prompts and outputs supported quality assurance

title: Example Use Case: Foodborne Illness Investigation
text:
5 Template for Similar Investigations
This example can serve as a template for other foodborne illness investigations by: 1. Following the same sequence of prompts 2. Adapting context to specific outbreak characteristics 3. Maintaining the systematic approach to evidence collection and analysis 4. Using consistent reporting formats







WarningDisclaimer



This is a fictional example created for educational purposes. Real outbreak investigations should always be conducted by qualified public health professionals following established protocols.

title: Documentation

title: Documentation
text: This section provides comprehensive guidance for using the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library effectively and safely in professional public health practice.

Usage Guidelines

text:
Quick Reference Guides

✅ Review Usage Guidelines
✅ Explore relevant prompt categories

Epidemiologist

title: Documentation
text:
Technical Documentation

AI Platform Compatibility
The library is designed to work with: - ChatGPT (OpenAI) - Claude (Anthropic) - Gemini (Google) - Custom API integrations - Local AI models


Integration Methods

Copy-Paste: Direct use in web interfaces
API Integration: Programmatic prompt management
Workflow Tools: Integration with existing systems
Custom Applications: Embedded in organization-specific tools

title: Documentation
text:
Quality Assurance

Validation Framework
All prompts undergo: - Technical review by AI/ML specialists - Domain review by public health experts - Testing with realistic scenarios - Community feedback integration


Continuous Improvement

Regular updates based on user feedback
Performance monitoring and optimization
Expansion based on community needs
Integration of latest AI best practices

title: Documentation
text:
Support Resources

Community Support

GitHub Discussions - Community Q&A
GitHub Issues - Bug reports and feature requests



Professional Networks

Public health AI communities
Epidemiology professional associations
Digital health working groups








ImportantProfessional Responsibility



Remember that AI tools are assistants, not replacements for professional judgment. Always:

Validate outputs with qualified experts
Follow organizational policies and procedures
Maintain appropriate professional standards
Ensure compliance with privacy regulations









NoteFeedback Welcome



Have suggestions for improving our documentation? Found something unclear? We welcome feedback through:

GitHub Issues for specific problems
GitHub Discussions for general feedback
Direct contributions via pull requests

title: Contributing Guidelines
text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library! This document provides guidelines for contributing new prompts, improving existing ones, and maintaining the quality of our collection.

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
How to Contribute

Types of Contributions

New Prompts: Add prompts for new use cases or domains
Prompt Improvements: Enhance existing prompts for clarity and effectiveness
Documentation: Improve README files, usage guides, and examples
Bug Reports: Report issues with existing prompts or documentation
Feature Requests: Suggest new categories or functionality



Getting Started

Fork the Repository: Create your own copy to work with
Create a Branch: Use descriptive branch names (e.g., add-vaccine-surveillance-prompts)
Make Changes: Follow our style guidelines and templates
Test Your Prompts: Validate prompts with real scenarios when possible
Submit a Pull Request: Include detailed description of changes

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Prompt Quality Standards

Content Requirements

Accuracy: Based on established public health methodologies
Clarity: Clear, unambiguous language and instructions
Completeness: All necessary context and variables included
Actionability: Generates specific, usable outputs
Ethical: Respects privacy, confidentiality, and professional standards



Format Requirements

Use the standard prompt template
Include appropriate metadata (category, tags, complexity)
Provide usage notes and examples
Follow markdown formatting standards



Testing Guidelines
Before submitting a prompt: 1. Test with at least 2-3 different scenarios 2. Verify outputs are appropriate and useful 3. Check for potential biases or limitations 4. Ensure compliance with privacy requirements

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Style Guide

Writing Style

Use clear, professional language
Write in active voice when possible
Be specific rather than generic
Include context that helps AI understand the domain



Structure

Start with clear purpose statement
Use consistent placeholder formats: [VARIABLE_NAME]
Include both required and optional inputs
Provide expected output format



Naming Conventions

File names: lowercase with hyphens (disease-surveillance.qmd)
Categories: lowercase with hyphens for folders
Variables: UPPERCASE with underscores in brackets

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Review Process

Peer Review
All contributions go through peer review to ensure: - Technical accuracy - Adherence to guidelines - Appropriate categorization - Clear documentation


Approval Criteria

Prompt produces useful, accurate outputs
Documentation is complete and clear
Follows established formatting standards
Adds value to existing collection

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Community Guidelines

Code of Conduct

Be respectful and professional
Focus on constructive feedback
Respect diverse perspectives and experiences
Maintain patient privacy and confidentiality



Communication

Use issue templates when reporting problems
Provide specific examples in discussions
Be patient with review processes
Ask for help when needed

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Recognition
Contributors are recognized through: - GitHub contributor listings - Acknowledgment in documentation - Community highlights for significant contributions

title: Contributing Guidelines
text:
Questions and Support

Issues: Technical problems or bug reports
Discussions: Questions, ideas, and community conversation
Email: Private inquiries to maintainers

Thank you for helping improve public health intelligence tools for our community!

title: Usage Guidelines
text: This document provides detailed guidance on how to effectively use the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library.

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
1 Getting Maximum Value

1.1 Before Using Prompts

Define Your Objective: Clearly understand what you want to achieve
Select Appropriate Category: Choose the most relevant prompt category
Review Multiple Options: Compare similar prompts to find the best fit
Understand Context: Read the full prompt description and usage notes



1.2 Customizing Prompts

1.2.1 Essential Customization Steps

Replace Placeholders: Fill in all bracketed variables with specific information
Add Context: Include relevant background information for your situation
Specify Constraints: Add any limitations, requirements, or special considerations
Define Output Format: Clarify how you want results presented



1.2.2 Example Customization
Original Prompt:
Analyze health data for [DISEASE] in [LOCATION] during [TIME_PERIOD]
Customized Prompt:
Analyze health data for influenza in New York County during January-March 2024, 
focusing on age-specific attack rates and geographic clustering. The dataset 
includes 1,247 confirmed cases with complete demographic information.



1.3 Working with AI Assistants

1.3.1 Prompt Engineering Tips

Be Specific: Provide concrete details rather than general statements
Use Context: Give AI relevant background information
Set Expectations: Clearly state what type of output you need
Iterate: Refine prompts based on initial responses
Validate: Always verify AI outputs with domain expertise



1.3.2 Common Improvements

Add Role Definition: “You are an experienced epidemiologist…”
Specify Format: “Provide results in a structured report with sections for…”
Include Examples: “Similar to the format used in CDC reports…”
Set Boundaries: “Focus only on [specific aspects]…”

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
2 Domain-Specific Guidance

2.1 Epidemiology

Include case definitions when relevant
Specify population demographics
Provide temporal and geographic scope
Mention data sources and quality



2.2 Surveillance

Define surveillance objectives
Specify target conditions or events
Include population coverage details
Mention reporting requirements



2.3 Data Analysis

Describe dataset characteristics
Specify analysis objectives
Include variable definitions
Mention software preferences



2.4 Risk Assessment

Define the specific threat or hazard
Include population characteristics
Specify assessment framework
Mention regulatory requirements

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
3 Quality Assurance

3.1 Validating AI Outputs

Subject Matter Review: Have domain experts review results
Cross-Reference: Compare with established guidelines and literature
Plausibility Check: Ensure recommendations are feasible and appropriate
Bias Assessment: Look for potential biases in analysis or recommendations



3.2 Common Issues to Watch For

Outdated Information: AI may use outdated practices or guidelines
Context Misunderstanding: AI might miss important contextual factors
Overgeneralization: Results may need local adaptation
Regulatory Compliance: Ensure outputs meet current requirements

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
4 Best Practices

4.1 Documentation

Keep records of prompts used and outputs generated
Document any modifications made to prompts
Track which prompts work best for different scenarios
Share successful adaptations with the community



4.2 Collaboration

Involve multidisciplinary teams in prompt selection and review
Share prompts and improvements with colleagues
Contribute back to the library with tested improvements
Participate in community discussions



4.3 Continuous Improvement

Regularly update prompts based on new evidence
Adapt prompts for local contexts and requirements
Test prompts with different AI models for consistency
Provide feedback to maintainers

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
5 Troubleshooting

5.1 Common Problems and Solutions






TipProblem: AI output is too general or vague



Solution: Add more specific context and constraints to the prompt








TipProblem: Output doesn’t match public health standards



Solution: Include specific guidelines or frameworks in the prompt








TipProblem: Analysis seems inappropriate for the data



Solution: Provide more detailed data characteristics in the prompt








TipProblem: Recommendations aren’t actionable



Solution: Specify the decision-making context and available resources

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
6 Advanced Techniques

6.1 Prompt Chaining
Use multiple prompts in sequence to build complex analyses: 1. Start with exploratory data analysis prompt 2. Follow with specific statistical testing prompt 3. Conclude with interpretation and recommendations prompt


6.2 Context Building
Gradually build context across multiple interactions: 1. Establish the scenario and objectives 2. Add data characteristics and constraints
3. Specify analysis requirements 4. Request interpretation and recommendations


6.3 Template Customization
Create organization-specific versions of prompts that include: - Local reporting requirements - Specific data sources and formats - Organizational terminology and procedures - Regulatory compliance requirements

title: Usage Guidelines
text:
7 Resources

Prompt Templates - Standard formats for new prompts
Examples - Complete use case demonstrations

Community Discussions - User experiences and tips

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text: This library provides ready-to-use prompts for epidemiologists, public health analysts, surveillance specialists, and other public health professionals to leverage AI tools effectively in their work.

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text: This library provides ready-to-use prompts for epidemiologists, public health analysts, surveillance specialists, and other public health professionals to leverage AI tools effectively in their work.

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
📚 Library Structure

Core Prompt Categories




🔬 Epidemiology

Disease investigation and analysis
Outbreak investigations, case definitions, contact tracing





👁️ Surveillance

Health monitoring systems
Syndromic surveillance, data quality, early warning





📊 Data Analysis

Statistical methods and interpretation
Descriptive statistics, regression, time series





📋 Reporting

Communication and documentation
Situation reports, policy briefs, technical summaries





⚠️ Risk Assessment

Health threat evaluation
Hazard identification, vulnerability analysis





🏛️ Policy

Public health policy development
Policy analysis, evidence synthesis, implementation





🚨 Emergency Response

Crisis management
Emergency planning, incident command, coordination





🤝 Community Health

Population health improvement
Health promotion, community engagement, education





🎓 Training & Education

Workforce development
Curriculum design, case studies, competency assessment

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
🚀 Getting Started

Quick Start Guide

Browse Categories: Navigate to the relevant category for your use case
Select Prompts: Choose prompts that match your specific needs

Customize: Adapt prompts with your specific context and data
Apply: Use with your preferred AI assistant or language model
Validate: Always review AI outputs with domain expertise



Example Usage
# Using an Outbreak Investigation Prompt

1. Go to Epidemiology > Outbreak Investigation
2. Copy the prompt template
3. Fill in your specific outbreak details:
   - Disease: Salmonellosis
   - Location: County X  
   - Cases: 45 confirmed cases
4. Submit to your AI assistant
5. Review recommendations with your epidemiology team

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
🎯 Key Features

🔬 Evidence-Based: Prompts grounded in established public health methodologies
📊 Structured Outputs: Designed to generate organized, actionable responses
🌍 Adaptable: Templates that work across different contexts and populations
⚡ Efficient: Save time on routine analyses and report generation
🔄 Iterative: Continuously updated based on user feedback and best practices

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
💡 Use Cases

For Epidemiologists

Standardize outbreak investigation procedures
Generate case definitions and analysis plans
Streamline contact tracing protocols



For Surveillance Specialists

Design surveillance system evaluations
Create data quality assessment frameworks
Develop early warning algorithms



For Public Health Analysts

Structure statistical analysis approaches
Generate data visualization strategies
Create interpretation guidelines



For Policy Makers

Synthesize evidence for policy development
Create stakeholder engagement strategies
Generate implementation planning frameworks

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
🔒 Privacy and Ethics






ImportantImportant Disclaimers




⚠️ Never include personally identifiable information (PII) in prompts
🔐 Follow your organization’s data governance policies

✅ Always validate AI outputs with subject matter experts
📋 Ensure compliance with applicable regulations (HIPAA, GDPR, etc.)

title: Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library
text:
🛠️ Technical Requirements

Compatible with major AI platforms (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, etc.)
Works with both API integrations and web interfaces
No special software required - just copy and paste


Disclaimer: This library is for educational and professional development purposes. AI outputs should always be validated by qualified public health professionals. The maintainers are not responsible for decisions made based on AI-generated content.

title: Examples & Use Cases
text: This section provides comprehensive examples of how to use the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library in real-world scenarios. Each example demonstrates the complete workflow from prompt selection to implementation.

title: Examples & Use Cases
text: This section provides comprehensive examples of how to use the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library in real-world scenarios. Each example demonstrates the complete workflow from prompt selection to implementation.

title: Examples & Use Cases
text:
Available Examples

Foodborne Illness Investigation
A complete step-by-step example demonstrating how to use multiple prompts from the library to conduct a foodborne illness outbreak investigation.
What you’ll learn: - How to select appropriate prompts for your use case - Step-by-step prompt customization process - Integration of multiple prompt outputs - Best practices for real-world implementation
Prompts demonstrated: - Outbreak Investigation Analysis (Epidemiology) - Emergency Risk Assessment (Risk Assessment)
- Weekly Surveillance Report (Reporting)

title: Examples & Use Cases
text:
How to Use These Examples

For New Users

Start here to understand the library’s practical applications
Follow the workflows to see complete implementation processes
Adapt the examples to your specific contexts and needs



For Experienced Users

Reference implementations for complex multi-prompt workflows
Best practice demonstrations for quality assurance
Template workflows for similar scenarios

title: Examples & Use Cases
text:

Multi-agency coordination examples



Reporting Workflows

Emergency communication protocols

title: Examples & Use Cases
text:
Contributing Examples
We welcome examples from the public health community!

What Makes a Good Example

Complete workflow from start to finish
Real-world relevance (using anonymized/fictional data)
Multiple prompt integration when applicable
Clear documentation of decision points
Lessons learned and best practices



Submission Process
See our Contributing Guidelines for: - Example submission requirements - Review process for new examples - Community feedback integration







NoteComing Soon



Additional examples are in development:

Policy Development Workflow: Evidence synthesis to implementation
Emergency Response Coordination: Multi-agency incident management
Community Health Assessment: Population health analysis and planning









TipHave a Success Story?



If you’ve successfully used the prompt library in your work, we’d love to feature your example (with appropriate anonymization). Contact us through GitHub Issues or Discussions.

title: Reporting Prompts
text: Public health reporting and communication prompts for various audiences.

title: Reporting Prompts
text:
Categories

Situation Reports - Crisis and outbreak reporting
Surveillance Reports - Regular health monitoring reports
Technical Briefs - Scientific and technical documentation
Policy Briefs - Evidence-based policy recommendations
Public Communications - General public health messaging
Executive Summaries - High-level decision maker reports

title: Reporting Prompts
text:
Report Types

Weekly/monthly surveillance summaries
Outbreak investigation reports
Health assessment reports
Program evaluation reports
Grant and funding reports

title: Reporting Prompts
text:
Available Prompts

Surveillance Reports






TipWeekly Surveillance Report



Weekly Surveillance Report Generation
Professional framework for generating weekly surveillance reports that communicate key findings to health officials and stakeholders.
Complexity: Intermediate | Tags: surveillance reporting, weekly reports, public health communication, data analysis, health monitoring

title: Reporting Prompts
text:
Getting Started

Identify your target audience (health officials, healthcare providers, public, etc.)
Determine report purpose (routine surveillance, outbreak response, policy support)
Gather relevant data and ensure quality checks are complete
Select appropriate prompt based on report type and audience needs

title: Reporting Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Tailor language and technical detail to your audience
Include appropriate disclaimers about data interpretation
Ensure consistent formatting across report series
Review for sensitive information before distribution
Use clear, actionable recommendations
Include contact information for follow-up questions
Maintain professional tone and objective presentation

title: Surveillance System Evaluation
text:
You are a surveillance system specialist tasked with evaluating the performance and effectiveness of a public health surveillance system. Help me conduct a comprehensive evaluation using CDC guidelines.
Surveillance System Details: - System name: [SPECIFY SYSTEM NAME] - Disease/condition monitored: [SPECIFY CONDITIONS] - Geographic coverage: [LOCAL/STATE/NATIONAL] - Duration of operation: [TIME PERIOD] - Reporting sources: [LIST DATA SOURCES]
Please evaluate the following attributes:



Assess ease of operation and maintenance
Evaluate data collection and reporting processes
Identify opportunities for simplification





Evaluate ability to adapt to changing information needs
Assess responsiveness to new health threats
Review system modification capabilities





Assess completeness, accuracy, and timeliness
Evaluate data validation procedures
Identify data quality improvement opportunities





Evaluate stakeholder willingness to participate
Assess reporting compliance and engagement
Identify barriers to participation





Estimate ability to detect cases/events
Assess coverage of target population
Evaluate case detection effectiveness





Assess proportion of reported cases that are true cases
Evaluate case verification processes
Identify false positive reduction strategies





Evaluate how well system describes disease occurrence
Assess population coverage and geographic representation
Identify potential biases in reporting





Assess speed of case detection and reporting
Evaluate time from onset to public health action
Identify bottlenecks and improvement opportunities





Assess system reliability and consistency
Evaluate resource availability and sustainability
Review operational continuity

System Context: [Provide details about system objectives, resources, legal framework, and operational environment]

title: Surveillance System Evaluation
text:
Usage Notes






Tip




Use standardized evaluation frameworks (CDC Guidelines)
Include quantitative metrics where possible
Provide actionable recommendations for improvement

title: Outbreak Investigation Analysis
text:
You are a public health epidemiologist investigating a potential disease outbreak. Based on the following information, help me conduct a systematic outbreak investigation:
Context: - Disease/condition: [SPECIFY DISEASE] - Location: [SPECIFY GEOGRAPHIC AREA] - Time period: [SPECIFY TIMEFRAME] - Population affected: [DESCRIBE POPULATION] - Number of cases: [SPECIFY CASE COUNT]
Please provide:



Develop a preliminary case definition (clinical criteria, time, place, person)
Suggest laboratory confirmation requirements if applicable





Outline key person, place, and time variables to analyze
Recommend appropriate attack rates and comparison groups





List potential sources and modes of transmission to investigate
Identify high-priority hypotheses based on the epidemiologic pattern





Prioritize immediate investigation activities
Recommend data collection strategies
Suggest control measures to consider





Draft key messages for different stakeholder groups
Identify when to issue public health alerts

Additional Context: [Add any specific details about the outbreak situation, population characteristics, or local factors that might influence the investigation]

title: Outbreak Investigation Analysis
text:

text:
Usage Notes






Important




Customize the bracketed placeholders with specific outbreak details

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text: Health risk evaluation and assessment prompts for public health decision-making.

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text:
Categories

Hazard Identification - Identifying potential health threats
Exposure Assessment - Evaluating population exposure levels
Dose-Response Assessment - Understanding health impact relationships
Risk Characterization - Comprehensive risk evaluation
Vulnerability Assessment - Population susceptibility analysis
Risk Communication - Conveying risk information effectively

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text:
Assessment Types

Environmental health risks
Infectious disease risks
Occupational health risks
Emergency preparedness risks
Population-specific risks

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text:
Available Prompts

Emergency Preparedness






TipEmergency Risk Assessment



Public Health Emergency Risk Assessment
Systematic approach to evaluating and characterizing public health risks during emergencies and threat scenarios.
Complexity: Advanced | Tags: risk assessment, emergency preparedness, threat evaluation, vulnerability analysis, emergency response

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text:
Getting Started

Define the threat or hazard you need to assess
Identify the population at risk and their characteristics
Gather available data on exposure, health effects, and vulnerabilities
Select the appropriate assessment framework based on threat type

title: Risk Assessment Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Use standardized risk assessment frameworks when available
Include uncertainty analysis and confidence intervals
Consider cumulative and combined exposures
Address vulnerable populations specifically
Update assessments as new information becomes available
Engage stakeholders throughout the assessment process
Communicate findings clearly with appropriate caveats

title: Health Promotion Campaign Development
text:
You are a community health specialist developing a health promotion campaign. Help me design an evidence-based, culturally appropriate campaign that effectively reaches and engages the target population.
Campaign Context: - Health issue/behavior: [SPECIFY TARGET HEALTH ISSUE] - Target population: [DEMOGRAPHICS, SIZE, CHARACTERISTICS] - Geographic area: [COMMUNITY/REGION DESCRIPTION] - Campaign duration: [TIMELINE] - Available resources: [BUDGET/STAFF/PARTNERSHIPS]
Community Assessment: - Health status indicators: [RELEVANT DATA] - Behavioral risk factors: [KEY BEHAVIORS TO ADDRESS] - Social determinants: [RELEVANT SOCIAL FACTORS] - Cultural considerations: [LANGUAGE, TRADITIONS, VALUES] - Existing resources: [COMMUNITY ASSETS AND SERVICES]
Please develop:



Primary and secondary objectives (SMART goals)
Key messages and call-to-action
Theoretical framework/behavior change model
Logic model connecting activities to outcomes





Primary audience segments and characteristics
Audience knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs
Preferred communication channels
Barriers and motivators to behavior change





Core messages for each audience segment
Key talking points and supporting facts
Cultural adaptations and language considerations
Message testing recommendations





Primary communication channels and rationale
Channel-specific message adaptations
Partnership opportunities for message dissemination
Digital and traditional media mix





Timeline and milestones
Resource allocation and staffing needs
Partnership roles and responsibilities
Quality assurance and monitoring procedures





Process indicators (reach, engagement, participation)
Outcome measures (knowledge, attitudes, behaviors)
Impact indicators (health outcomes, system changes)
Data collection methods and timeline





Long-term funding and resource needs
Community capacity building elements
Policy and environmental change opportunities
Transition planning for ongoing activities

Special Considerations: [Any specific requirements, constraints, or focus areas]

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text: Statistical analysis and data interpretation prompts for public health intelligence.

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text:
Categories

Descriptive Statistics - Summarizing and describing health data
Statistical Testing - Hypothesis testing and inference
Regression Analysis - Modeling relationships in health data
Time Series Analysis - Analyzing trends over time
Geospatial Analysis - Spatial patterns in health data
Data Visualization - Creating effective health data visualizations

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text:
Analysis Types

Univariate and multivariate analysis
Comparative studies
Trend analysis
Risk factor identification
Predictive modeling

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text:
Available Prompts

Statistical Testing






TipStatistical Analysis



Health Data Statistical Analysis
Expert guidance on selecting appropriate statistical methods and developing analysis plans for public health surveillance and research projects.
Complexity: Intermediate | Tags: statistical analysis, biostatistics, data analysis, epidemiology, surveillance

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text:
Getting Started

Define your analysis objectives clearly before selecting a prompt
Describe your data characteristics including study design, sample size, and variable types
Specify your target population and any special considerations
Consider the public health context of your analysis

title: Data Analysis Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Always validate statistical assumptions before applying recommended methods
Consider both statistical and public health significance
Account for potential confounders and effect modifiers
Use appropriate visualization techniques for your audience
Document your analysis approach for reproducibility
Seek subject matter expert review of results and interpretations

title: Policy Development Prompts
text: Public health policy development and analysis prompts.

title: Policy Development Prompts
text:
Categories

Policy Analysis - Evaluating existing policies and their impacts
Policy Development - Creating new public health policies
Evidence Synthesis - Integrating research into policy recommendations
Stakeholder Engagement - Involving communities in policy development
Implementation Planning - Strategies for policy implementation
Policy Evaluation - Assessing policy effectiveness and outcomes

title: Policy Development Prompts
text:
Policy Areas

Health promotion and disease prevention
Health equity and social determinants
Environmental health regulations
Emergency preparedness policies
Healthcare system policies

title: Policy Development Prompts
text:
Available Prompts






NoteComing Soon



Policy development prompts are currently under development. These will include comprehensive frameworks for:

Policy brief development
Stakeholder analysis and engagement
Evidence review and synthesis
Impact assessment methodologies
Implementation planning strategies
Policy evaluation frameworks

title: Policy Development Prompts
text:
Getting Started
When policy development prompts become available, they will help you:

Analyze existing policies for gaps and effectiveness
Develop evidence-based recommendations using best practices
Engage stakeholders throughout the policy development process
Plan implementation strategies that consider local contexts

title: Policy Development Prompts
text:
Best Practices

Base policy recommendations on strong evidence
Engage diverse stakeholders early and often
Consider health equity implications in all policies
Plan for implementation challenges and barriers
Include evaluation metrics from the beginning
Address social determinants of health
Ensure policies are culturally appropriate and feasible

title: Prompt Templates
text: This section provides standardized templates for creating new prompts that maintain consistency and quality across the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library.

title: Prompt Templates
text: This section provides standardized templates for creating new prompts that maintain consistency and quality across the Public Health Intelligence Prompts Library.

title: Prompt Templates
text:
Available Templates

Standard Prompt Template
The core template for creating new prompts in any category. This template ensures:

Consistent structure and formatting
Complete metadata and documentation
Clear usage instructions and examples
Appropriate categorization and tagging

title: Prompt Templates
text:
Template Usage Guidelines

When to Use Templates

New Prompt Creation: Always start with the standard template
Prompt Updates: Use template sections to ensure completeness
Quality Review: Check existing prompts against template requirements



Best Practices

Complete All Sections: Don’t skip template sections
Test Before Submitting: Validate prompts with real scenarios
Follow Naming Conventions: Use consistent file and variable naming
Include Examples: Provide concrete usage examples
Add Metadata: Complete all tags, complexity, and domain fields

title: Prompt Templates
text:
Contributing New Templates
Have an idea for a specialized template? See our Contributing Guidelines for:

Template proposal process
Review and approval workflow
Community feedback integration








TipQuick Start



Ready to create a new prompt? Start with our Standard Prompt Template and follow the embedded instructions.
